item.title: A Dad Takes His Son To The Doctor And Discovers Fear Of Vaccines
item.description: June 10, 2017 - As a science journalist, I know vaccines are safe. But when it was time to take my son to get his shots, I suddenly found myself overwhelmed by fear. Does science stand a chance against emotion?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 10, 2017 - As a science journalist, I know vaccines are safe. But when it was time to take my son to get his shots, I suddenly found myself overwhelmed by fear. Does science stand a chance against emotion? http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/10/532110787/a-dad-takes-his-son-to-the-doctor-and-discovers-fear-of-vaccines

item.title: FDA Asks Drug Maker To Pull Opioid Opana ER Off The Market
item.description: June 9, 2017 - The Food and Drug Administration requested drug maker Endo Pharmaceuticals stop selling Opana ER, which is an opioid. NPR's Robert Siegel speaks with Dr. Janet Woodcock, director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, about the decision.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 9, 2017 - The Food and Drug Administration requested drug maker Endo Pharmaceuticals stop selling Opana ER, which is an opioid. NPR's Robert Siegel speaks with Dr. Janet Woodcock, director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, about the decision. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/09/532289054/fda-asks-drug-maker-to-pull-opioid-opana-er-off-the-market

item.title: Got Cancer Questions? This Little-Known Hotline Is Here To Help
item.description: June 9, 2017 - For 40 years, people have been able to call a service funded by the National Cancer Institute to get information about cancer treatments. Doctors say it's still useful even in the age of Twitter.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 9, 2017 - For 40 years, people have been able to call a service funded by the National Cancer Institute to get information about cancer treatments. Doctors say it's still useful even in the age of Twitter. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/09/532230703/got-cancer-questions-this-little-known-hotline-is-here-to-help

item.title: FDA Calls On Drugmaker To Pull A Powerful Opioid Off The Market
item.description: June 8, 2017 - The Food and Drug Administration says abuse of the painkiller Opana ER has fueled an outbreak of HIV, hepatitis C and a serious blood disorder, though it was reformulated to try to reduce abuse.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - The Food and Drug Administration says abuse of the painkiller Opana ER has fueled an outbreak of HIV, hepatitis C and a serious blood disorder, though it was reformulated to try to reduce abuse. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/532126206/fda-calls-on-drugmaker-to-pull-a-powerful-opioid-off-the-market

item.title: CDC Reveals Sharper Numbers Of Zika Birth Defects From U.S. Territories
item.description: June 8, 2017 - About 5 percent of pregnant women infected with Zika in Puerto Rico and other U.S. territories last year had babies with birth defects, says the federal health agency. And the risk isn't over.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - About 5 percent of pregnant women infected with Zika in Puerto Rico and other U.S. territories last year had babies with birth defects, says the federal health agency. And the risk isn't over. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/532087184/cdc-reveals-sharper-numbers-of-zika-birth-defects-from-u-s-territories

item.title: Aid-In-Dying Requires More Than Just A Law, Californians Find
item.description: June 8, 2017 - In the year since the state enacted a law allowing doctors to prescribe lethal drugs for terminal patients who request it, over 500 people have sought that help. But some doctors are still reluctant.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - In the year since the state enacted a law allowing doctors to prescribe lethal drugs for terminal patients who request it, over 500 people have sought that help. But some doctors are still reluctant. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/530944807/aid-in-dying-requires-more-than-just-a-law-californians-find

item.title: Fetuses Respond To Face-Like Patterns, Study Suggests
item.description: June 8, 2017 - Fetuses in the third trimester responded more often to patterns that resembled faces than patterns that did not. The findings don't mean fetuses can recognize their parents' faces before they're born.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - Fetuses in the third trimester responded more often to patterns that resembled faces than patterns that did not. The findings don't mean fetuses can recognize their parents' faces before they're born. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/532051762/fetuses-respond-to-face-like-patterns-study-suggests

item.title: Invisibilia: Should Wild Bears Be Feared Or Befriended?
item.description: June 8, 2017 - A photographer who walks deep into the woods in search of a wild bear wonders if his curiosity will overcome his fear. Can bears and humans co-exist?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - A photographer who walks deep into the woods in search of a wild bear wonders if his curiosity will overcome his fear. Can bears and humans co-exist? http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/531787586/invisibilia-should-wild-bears-be-feared-or-befriended

item.title: Learn To Sniff Like A Dog And Experience The World In A New Way
item.description: June 8, 2017 - We humans think we don't have a very good sense of smell. But psychologist Alexandra Horowitz says dogs can show us how to train our noses so they give us a window into a secret world.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - We humans think we don't have a very good sense of smell. But psychologist Alexandra Horowitz says dogs can show us how to train our noses so they give us a window into a secret world. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/531744473/learn-to-sniff-like-a-dog-and-experience-the-world-in-a-new-way

item.title: If You See Dirty Water, Don't Just Gripe. Talk To The Cloud!
item.description: June 7, 2017 - Scientists and activists in India are training citizens to collect information on water issues like contamination — and upload it so it can be used to push for change.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - Scientists and activists in India are training citizens to collect information on water issues like contamination — and upload it so it can be used to push for change. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/06/07/527898124/if-you-see-dirty-water-dont-just-gripe-talk-to-the-cloud

item.title: Some Small Tumors In Breasts May Not Be So Bad After All
item.description: June 7, 2017 - Research indicates a significant number of the tumors detected through mammography are small because they are prone to slow growth. The findings suggest many are unlikely to become life-threatening.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - Research indicates a significant number of the tumors detected through mammography are small because they are prone to slow growth. The findings suggest many are unlikely to become life-threatening. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/07/531786168/some-small-tumors-in-breasts-may-not-be-so-bad-after-all

item.title: 315,000-Year-Old Fossils From Morocco Could Be Earliest Recorded Homo Sapiens
item.description: June 7, 2017 - Scientists who found the fossils believe they are the remains of five people and far older than all previous finds. But how do the remains really fit into the bushy family tree of modern humans?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - Scientists who found the fossils believe they are the remains of five people and far older than all previous finds. But how do the remains really fit into the bushy family tree of modern humans? http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/07/531804528/315-000-year-old-fossils-from-morocco-could-be-earliest-recorded-homo-sapiens

item.title: If The Individual Insurance Market Crashes, Can People Still Get Coverage?
item.description: June 7, 2017 - The Trump administration is putting pressure on the fragile market for individuals who buy their own health coverage, which will almost certainly mean higher prices and fewer choices next year.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - The Trump administration is putting pressure on the fragile market for individuals who buy their own health coverage, which will almost certainly mean higher prices and fewer choices next year. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/07/531885293/if-the-individual-insurance-market-crashes-can-people-still-get-coverage

item.title: 'The Trump 10': Packing On The Pounds In An Age Of Stressful Politics
item.description: June 7, 2017 - Think of it as the political version of the freshman 15. Nowadays, some people who are unhappy with the current political environment are complaining of stress-induced eating and weight gain.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - Think of it as the political version of the freshman 15. Nowadays, some people who are unhappy with the current political environment are complaining of stress-induced eating and weight gain. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/06/07/531859819/the-trump-10-packing-on-the-pounds-in-an-age-of-stressful-politics

item.title: Hospitals Are Partnering With Lawyers To Treat Patients' Legal Needs
item.description: June 6, 2017 - Roughly 300 health care systems around the country have set up medical-legal collaborations to help patients solve legal problems that can affect their health — at little or no cost to the patients.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 6, 2017 - Roughly 300 health care systems around the country have set up medical-legal collaborations to help patients solve legal problems that can affect their health — at little or no cost to the patients. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/06/531760445/hospitals-are-partnering-with-lawyers-to-treat-patients-legal-needs
